The Company owns 36 television stations serving 30 television markets. 17 of Gray's stations are affiliated with the CBS Network owned by CBS Inc. Topic.Title: I've seen three law firms initiate investigations already

Message.Msg: As I posted here yesterday, there are lawsuits for every single merger or acquisition of a public company. For a large deal like DELL there will be more than a dozen lawsuits. The reason for the suits has nothing to do with acquisition price. Instead, through litigation law firms will be allowed to do a discovery process. The lawyers are after settlement fees, which are paid by the insurance companies representing the involved company's. in a deal like this a dozen law firms will share about $2 million worth of settlement fees. Actually, Dell, silverlake, Microsoft, banks etc.... want the lawsuits because it gives the LBO credibility and protects it from future litigation.

Message.Title: SEC cracking down on Executive trades
Message.Msg: Well SEC should take a look at Michael Dell for the ultimate insider trading scandal. SEC Expands Probe On Executive Trades By Susan Pulliam | The Wall Street Journal – 12 hours ago.. . . The Securities and Exchange Commission, expanding a high-profile investigation, is gathering data on a broad number of trades by corporate executives in shares of their own companies, according to people familiar with the probe. At issue is whether corporate executives are improperly taking advantage in their trading of access to private information about their businesses. Corporate executives, like all investors, are prohibited under securities laws from trading when they possess important, nonpublic information about their companies that can have an impact on the stock. The development comes on the heels of an article in The Wall Street Journal that highlighted well-timed and profitable trades by seven executives in shares of their own companies. Following the article, the SEC and Federal Bureau of Investigation began looking into the seven examples and the Manhattan U.S. attorney's office sent subpoenas to five of the seven companies. The new push by regulators goes beyond the seven companies named in the Journal article to a larger field of trades by executives. On Monday, one of those companies, VeriFone Systems Inc., said in a regulatory filing that the SEC and Manhattan U.S. attorney's office had notified the company that they had concluded their inquiries and that "no claim, action or other proceeding was asserted by either authority." The Journal article stemmed from an analysis of 20,000 government filings by executives over an eight-year period. Among the findings was that 1,418 executives who traded their company stock in the week before news was announced averaged gains of 10%—or avoided losses of 10%—within a week of their trades. The Journal analysis was based on a computer program the newspaper developed. The SEC is developing a similar computerized approach to analyze company-insider filings, a person familiar with the probe says. The article also exposed shortcomings of the regulations regarding corporate-insider trading, including loopholes in the rules that allow executives to trade even when they possess private knowledge about their companies if they establish preset trading arrangements, known as a 10b5-1 plans. Companies aren't required to disclose—even to the SEC—the existence, termination or changes to such plans. Investors, including the Council of Institutional Investors, which represents pension funds totaling more than $3 trillion in assets, petitioned the SEC after the Journal article to revamp the rules and provide better disclosure about such plans. "This is a significant expansion" of the probe, said James Cox, a law professor at Duke University, adding that the focus is increasing awareness of a "phenomenon that people have been talking about for a long time, and that is that executives have been abusing 10b5-1 plans and using them to provide a smoke screen for what would otherwise be labeled insider trading." The statement by VeriFone followed a presentation by the company to the SEC and the Manhattan U.S. attorney's office in which it argued that trading by Douglas Bergeron, VeriFone's CEO, was in compliance with the law. VeriFone previously said Mr. Bergeron always had traded through preset plans.

Message.Title: Sold today
Message.Msg: I think the odds of another offer coming in are very low and the odds of something derailing the deal could actually be higher than imagined. Overall, it seems that the odds are strong that this will indeed get done at $13.65, and thus it's not worth waiting many months for 25 cents. They will NOT sweeten the deal. Forget it. The only hope for longs now is if someone else makes a bid. Not something I would bet on. If any of these lawsuits gain traction, then one can revisit going long. Conversely, you could get a solid "HP making an offer" rumour and see this thing spike temporarily. To the posters who said it would trade higher than the offer price when the news was made official - as I said, you were wrong. Hopefully you learned something. Those who think that each and every one of the lawsuits that will be brought will be without merit might be sadly mistaken. Yes, there are always frivolous lawsuits in these types of deals. Agreed. Goes with the territory. However, this is a very special and unique situation. We shall see. Sold at a small profit (was in at $12.70 average). Was thinking $14.50 was a realistic figure, but it was not to be. That's life. Still have my currently worthless puts just in case something does go wrong. Good luck.

Message.Title: SEC expands probe into trading by executives
Message.Msg: Well they should start an investigation by Michael Dell. SEC expands probe on trading by executives: The Securities and Exchange Commission, expanding a high-profile investigation, is gathering data on a broad number of trades by corporate executives in shares of their own companies, according to people familiar with the probe. At issue is whether corporate executives are improperly taking advantage in their trading of access to private information about their businesses. Corporate executives, like all investors, are prohibited under securities laws from trading when they possess important, nonpublic information about their companies that can have an impact on the stock. The development comes on the heels of an article in The Wall Street Journal that highlighted well-timed and profitable trades by seven executives in shares of their own companies. Following the article, the SEC and Federal Bureau of Investigation began looking into the seven examples and the Manhattan U.S. attorney's office sent subpoenas to five of the seven companies. The new push by regulators goes beyond the seven companies named in the Journal article to a larger field of trades by executives. On Monday, one of those companies, VeriFone Systems Inc., said in a regulatory filing that the SEC and Manhattan U.S. attorney's office had notified the company that they had concluded their inquiries and that "no claim, action or other proceeding was asserted by either authority." The Journal article stemmed from an analysis of 20,000 government filings by executives over an eight-year period. Among the findings was that 1,418 executives who traded their company stock in the week before news was announced averaged gains of 10%—or avoided losses of 10%—within a week of their trades. The Journal analysis was based on a computer program the newspaper developed. The SEC is developing a similar computerized approach to analyze company-insider filings, a person familiar with the probe says. The article also exposed shortcomings of the regulations regarding corporate-insider trading, including loopholes in the rules that allow executives to trade even when they possess private knowledge about their companies if they establish preset trading arrangements, known as a 10b5-1 plans. Companies aren't required to disclose—even to the SEC—the existence, termination or changes to such plans. Investors, including the Council of Institutional Investors, which represents pension funds totaling more than $3 trillion in assets, petitioned the SEC after the Journal article to revamp the rules and provide better disclosure about such plans. "This is a significant expansion" of the probe, said James Cox, a law professor at Duke University, adding that the focus is increasing awareness of a "phenomenon that people have been talking about for a long time, and that is that executives have been abusing 10b5-1 plans and using them to provide a smoke screen for what would otherwise be labeled insider trading." The statement by VeriFone followed a presentation by the company to the SEC and the Manhattan U.S. attorney's office in which it argued that trading by Douglas Bergeron, VeriFone's CEO, was in compliance with the law. VeriFone previously said Mr. Bergeron always had traded through preset plans.
